ANSWER.PARA: There have been several studies of these workers and of other workers at the nitro factory. These studies were considered by the Evatt Royal Commission on the use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam. The studies have been portrayed as central to Justice Evatt's conclusions. However, the nitro accident was only one of a number of industrial accidents considered by the Royal Commission. Discussion of the nitro studies comprises approximately 10 pages out of the 400 pages of the volume of the Royal Commission report dealing with cancer. Based on a preliminary analysis of the material that has been made available, it appears that mistakes may have been made in the exposure classification of a small number of workers. This is different from fraud and falsification.

It is hard to reconcile the allegation that results were deliberately suppressed when the published study clearly showed a ten-fold increase in cancer of the bladder. It was acknowledged that a chemical used in the rubber industry was also processed at the factory and had been confirmed as causing bladder cancer.

Those raising the allegations against Monsanto have ignored another study discussed in the same section of the Royal Commission report. The study was commissioned by the nitro workers union and was carried out by a research group quite independent of Monsanto. That also concluded that workers exposed to dioxin were unlikely to suffer permanent and debilitating health effects.

Charges of scientific fraud are serious and further investigations are being made. However, it appears at this stage that both the allegations and their impact on Justice Evatt's conclusions have been exaggerated. In the latter part of the honourable senator's question certain further considerations are asked to be undertaken by the Minister. I will, as I say, bring that part of the honourable senator's question to the Minister's attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health been drawn to an article in the Australian newspaper of 15 May 1990, is which the President of the New South Wales branch of the Australian Medical Association, Dr Shepherd, called for a moratorium on the entry of foreign medical practitioners into Australia? Is Dr Shepherd correct in claiming that a `further influx of foreign doctors would cause Australia's high standards of medical practice to deteriorate'? Is the increasing number of foreign medical graduates likely to cause poorer training opportunities, excessive training costs, unemployment and a fall in the level of skills, as Dr Shepherd suggests?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some information on the question that Senator Colston raises. From my general reading I understand that at the moment Dr Bruce Shepherd is involved in an election campaign within the Australian Medical Association. I believe that the scaremongering and the utterly unfounded assertions that he has made, as conveyed to the Senate by Senator Colston, are simply part of that election campaign. I certainly do not want to add to any notoriety that he might be seeking by appealing in a xenophobic way to people's fears in the way that he has.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia has an overall adequate supply of doctors but there are sectoral shortages, such as in certain public hospitals, particularly in some rural areas-I notice Senator Watson nodding; he knows of some problems in Tasmania-and, of course, in some specialties. Attempts to overcome those shortages in those sectors would have been unsuccessful had recruiting drives been limited to Australia. Therefore it is quite clear that recruitment from overseas is essential if those particular shortages are to be satisfied.

Before doctors are able to be recruited from overseas under the employer nomination scheme, the recruiting organisation must demonstrate that it has made a genuine, though unsuccessful, attempt to recruit within Australia. Of course, we know that other doctors are admitted into Australia under different immigration programs such as family reunion or refugee programs. It would be quite improper to deny persons from overseas the possibility of coming in under those programs simply because of their professional status as doctors. Once migrants are admitted, the Government believes that they all should have the opportunity to use the skills which they have applied overseas, particularly professional skills which may be useful to our people.

Doctors can practise in Australia only if they obtain registration, which is mandatory. That registration process is designed to protect Australia's very high medical care standards. There will be no undermining of those standards by the Australian Medical Council. The final point to make is that it is the Australian Medical Council which is the arbiter of standards for overseas trained doctors. I believe that that Council sets extremely high standards-so high, in fact, that they have been queried by many who, having obtained qualifications overseas, seek to practise medicine in Australia. The allegations made by Dr Bruce Shepherd are quite unfounded in the light of that particular structure to ensure that the very highest standards are adhered to in the practice of medicine in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In light of statements by the Prime Minister yesterday that there will be `marginal real improvements in the standard of living' this year, has the Minister changed his view that it is unrealistic to talk about rising living standards in the current state of the economy?

—As I said in the Senate earlier this week, there is always a debate about the appropriate measure of living standards. We had the same debate in the Senate last year. As I recall, Senator Durack was not on the front bench, so he may not have heard it all; he may have been asleep. But there was an ongoing debate about the appropriate measure for living standards. At the time the Opposition view was that it was based on incomes; the government view was that it was based on household disposable income across the community. As I said in a television interview on Sunday, by that measure of household disposable income there had been rising living standards. Whether there will continue to be or not remains to be seen. I am unable to take the matter any further than that.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to the significant and welcome drop in the national road toll last year. Is it possible that a significant contributor to that reduction was the Government's policy decision to reduce excise tax on low alcohol beers absolutely, from 24 August 1988?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do believe it was a contributing factor in two ways: firstly, the sheer financial aspect of reducing the cost of the product even to a relatively minor degree, I guess, has to be considered, but I think the major impact of the Government's decision in terms of the feedback that I have got on it is that it added greatly to the whole education process which is going on in the Australian community and, given some leadership by governments, both Federal and State, I do believe it is having an effect. I am talking about the move to introduce random breath testing, which has had a major impact on community attitudes towards drink driving, not simply because of the risk of getting caught but because of the atmosphere created-it is not an appropriate thing these days simply to accept that we can drink with impunity, as used to be the case in terms of community attitudes, and drive a motor vehicle.

ANSWER.PARA: That is also allied of course to the current initiatives the Government is trying to introduce in concert with this proposal that was introduced to get a national blood alcohol limit of .05. In terms of road fatalities, perhaps in a lot of ways I guess it is hard to say what the cause is, but the major factors when serious injury is caused to people who in fact survive road vehicle accidents are of course carelessness, followed by speed and alcohol-and, quite often of course, those three combined. Thirty-eight per cent of all drivers killed in road accidents in 1987 did have a blood alcohol concentration of .05 or over. That represented the unnecessary loss of 500 Australian lives in that year alone. It is axiomatic to say that a driver who consumes low alcohol beer, encouraged by this Government initiative, will stay below the legal limit for a longer period of time. That is obvious.

Just as important, of course, as consuming low alcohol beer is the legal blood alcohol concentration limit. There is a very convincing array of information-and I might say this in response to some of the interjections that I heard from Opposition benches yesterday during a question from Senator Lees-demonstrating that .05 does save lives. There is an equally convincing array of medical and physiological evidence that shows that any level of alcohol in the blood stream impairs performance. I am sure there are many people who can attest to that. For that reason, of course, it has been thought proper that in particularly sensitive jobs such as flying aircraft there should be no alcohol consumed at all.

There are unfortunately two States-South Australia and Western Australia-and indeed the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory, which still have alcohol concentration limits of .08, and discussions to change that are continuing. A number of studies have shown that performance on driver-related tasks is significantly impaired at very low blood alcohol levels, as I have said before. In simple terms the risk of an accident at .05 is twice that at zero, whilst at .08 the risk is twice that at .05 and therefore four times that at zero.

The strongest evidence-and always the proof of the pudding is in the eating-comes from studies of the actual change from .08 to .05 in the States of New South Wales and Queensland. In both States the lower limit reduced the number of alcohol-related accidents. Accident costs were reduced by an estimated $76m in New South Wales and $32m in Queensland. It is important to stress that this is putting a large buffer between the legal limit and a blood alcohol level of .10.

I thank Senator Maguire for his question and I point out that there is ample evidence that these Government initiatives of lowering the excise and attempting to get a national limit of .05 are having positive results in reducing the trauma and the cost of road accidents.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Has his attention been drawn to the comments of Professor Ross Garnaut that, in relation to the economy, the argument over whether Australia faced a recession or a severe downturn is a `silly, semantic discussion'? Professor Garnaut said:

QUESTION.PARA: It's very likely that we'll have much lower business investment, a big decline in employment growth, probably a noticeable rise in unemployment and probably a number of quarters with virtually no growth.
Does the Minister share Professor Garnaut's views on the future of Australia's economy?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the article by Professor Garnaut. I would like to read it in its proper context and at this stage I would not comment on it.

—I have a supplementary question, Mr President. On the basis that I have read the complete article to the Senate, I ask Senator Button whether he agrees with Professor Garnaut's views. If not, why does he find that on this occasion his views are different when on every other occasion he has agreed with Professor Garnaut?

—I have not agreed with Professor Garnaut's views on every occasion. In terms of the first part of the question, I agree with Professor Garnaut's alleged view that there were a lot of semantics in this discussion. That is true. These questions are matters of degree. If I might use the word `semantics', as Professor Garnaut did, I understand that that means--
—Matters of emphasis.

—Matters of emphasis. Senator Durack is extraordinarily on the ball this morning and I thank him for his interjection. These are matters of degree. I suppose that each of us has subjective views about the degree of the current economic situation.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is the Minister aware that Qantas Airways Ltd screened only 11 Australian in-flight movies in the three-year period 1987 to 1989? Does the Minister concede that Qantas passengers, offered a majority of films such as Turner and Hooch and Cookie, could believe that they were en route to New York rather than Sydney? As Australian films have done so much to promote this country's tourist industry, can the Government encourage Qantas and the Australian film industry to cooperate to ensure that a more representative number of Australian films are screened on a much more regular basis?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish that I had been in a position to be on a Qantas flight recently so I could have seen what films were being shown. That has not been the case. I might be able to rectify that shortly.
—What do you mean? Do you mean that you do not travel Qantas when you go overseas?
—I always travel Qantas, Senator Puplick. I just serve the people and do not get to go overseas very often.

ANSWER.PARA: Obviously 11 Australian films in three years is no great number, and that is to be regretted. The point to be made here is that Qantas actually does consult the Australian Film Commission on what Australian films are appropriate for showing. Qantas also has to take into account the desire, if you like, of passengers and their preferences. It may well be that not just Qantas passengers but a lot of people like to see films such as Turner and Hooch. I saw it. I thought it was a pretty good show, so I cannot knock the fact that it was shown.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us.

—It was a nice dog, Senator Ray. I think one has to acknowledge that in the last few years the Australian film industry has not produced quite the amount it did in the previous few years. But now that the Government's $150m investment in the Australian Film Finance Corporation is starting to come through and feed its way into the industry itself, there will be a greatly increased number of films from which to choose and Qantas is confident that, in the course of the next 12 months, it will be showing many more Australian films than it has in the past and it will be satisfied with the quality and the quantity of them. So I acknowledge that it has been a problem, but it is being addressed, both by Qantas and in terms of the film industry itself. I think in a very short period of time Senator Reynolds will be able to get on that plane again and see an Australian film.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. How many children are living in poverty in Australia at the present time?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The poverty figures for children in Australia are impossible to give, mainly because there has never been an accepted definition of poverty. Whether one wants to take the Henderson line or other lines below and above it, it is very difficult. So I do not intend to put a number on it. I think that is very difficult to do, and I am not about doing it. What the Government sought to do in the course of the last few years with those targets of 15 and 20 per cent, which we have now met via family allowances and family allowance supplements, was to make sure that those children in Australia who were living in conditions that we did not think were appropriate were able to be assisted. This Government now has, because of its adoption of those targets and its capacity to meet them, which we have now done, made sure that those children at least have the opportunity to have their standards lifted. That is something of which we will always be proud. It does not mean that the battle is over. Obviously it will continue.

ANSWER.PARA: When the Prime Minister talked about doing something on child poverty he made sure that the Government moved immediately and we are proud of our efforts. That does not mean, of course, that every parent then takes those family allowances and family allowance supplements and uses them properly in terms of looking after their children. There are some parents who have not done that. That is to be regretted, but it is not something that the Government can legislate about. What we will do, however, is make sure that those efforts not only continue but are improved. We will make sure that family allowance and family allowance supplements continue to be indexed. Though Senator Alston was not here, when some of his colleagues who were around during the Fraser-Howard years were in government I have to report sadly that they could not index payments for children. They could not even index them. They had that typical miserable attitude that conservative parties always have.

In the course of the last election it was fascinating to watch all of the leadership of the party to which Senator Alston belongs-he probably cannot remember them now; they are fading fast-trying to duck the question of where the cuts they promised would come. We over here knew where they would come. Social security has always been a target, because members of the Opposition do not care about the poor.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Putting aside the gratuitous slander, I ask whether the Minister is saying that he has no idea of the level of child poverty in Australia at the present time. If that is so, how long has it been the case and on what basis was the Prime Minister able to pontificate three years ago?

—I think Senator Alston did not quite hear what I said before. I said that it is very difficult to say exactly what the poverty line is. That does not mean that there are not numbers in and around it. It is just impossible to say exactly what the poverty line is and I do not intend to do so.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DRUG TRAFFICKING: CONFISCATED ASSETS TRUST FUND

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. How will the confiscated assets trust fund, announced by the Prime Minister on 20 March 1990, operate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators would be aware of the program of the Government to strip major federal offenders-particularly those who involve themselves in the importing of drugs into this country-of the accumulated profits that they have made out of their nefarious criminal activity. The old aphorism used to run that crime does not pay, but of course we know that, particularly in relation to drug trafficking, crime does pay very large dollars indeed. Therefore the Government has, under the Proceeds of Crime Act and under the Customs Act, instituted a process whereby the accumulated profits of drug traffickers in particular can be stripped away from them in a way which not only hurts them personally and is an added individual punishment-they hate losing their palatial car, the luxury yacht and the horse stud-but also strips them of the assets which they can use for further criminal activity. This is an excellent way in which we can combat organised crime in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister announced during the election campaign that the assets and the moneys which are confiscated will be put into a special fund, and 50 per cent of the moneys accumulated in that fund will be relayed back to law enforcement agencies and 50 per cent will go into drug education and rehabilitation projects. I think honourable senators would agree that this is an excellent use of these moneys, turning the moneys of organised crime back to the law enforcement agencies to continue the battle and, more particularly perhaps and more satisfactorily, to provide for drug rehabilitation projects for those who have fallen victim to drug abuse. While it is impossible to put a very firm figure on this, it is expected that the trust fund will distribute around $3m per year in this way and I hope to introduce the legislation in the Budget sittings. I expect and hope that the Senate will give support to that legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. The Minister will be aware that in 1989 his predecessor, Mr Howe, boasted that, whilst the Australian social security system was far from perfect, at least it ensured that we have no beggars on the street. In view of the findings of the recent report by VCOSS, the Victorian Council of Social Service, which suggests that one in three Victorians on social security benefits are forced into off-street begging for emergency assistance at least three times a year, does the Minister acknowledge that the Australian social security system does have significant problems? Would the Minister please indicate what steps he proposes to take to remedy this totally unacceptable situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of that VCOSS report which suggested that there were a number of Department of Social Security beneficiaries who were forced into approaching charitable organisations for hand-outs from time to time. That has always been the case. I do not think it contradicts Mr Howe's statement. Nonetheless, it is obviously a matter of regret. There is no doubt that some beneficiaries, particularly those who for any one of quite a number of reasons go off benefits for any period, find themselves in acute difficulties. Often that is their own fault. Sometimes they are merely the victims of circumstances. When that happens there is a safety net in charitable organisations, as there is in all the developed countries, to assist in looking after them.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact that those organisations exist does not mean that the objectives of a proper social security system are not met. It simply means that government cannot ever meet every need. What we are proud of though is that during the course of the seven years of the Hawke Government we have massively increased our payments to social security beneficiaries and we have made sure that, as I said only a few moments ago, children in particular have benefited by the family allowance and family allowance supplements. So we have certainly eased the burden. But that is not to claim that we have eliminated it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Could the Minister answer the last part of my question? What steps, given that the Minister admits some people are falling between the stools, does he propose to take to remedy this unacceptable situation?

—During the course of the last few years in particular some enormous changes have taken place in social security, and as a result of those changes the Government has had a complete review of the system. A review on disabilities is currently under way, and that is one area that I will be addressing shortly. I will not lay down my own priorities for the next few years. I have been in the job only a few weeks, and I want to take some more time to go through that review properly and to see what the disability review throws up before I lay down any pronouncements from on high. I think to do so would be foolish. As Senator Patterson ought to do, I intend to find out, and during the course of the next few months I will do so, and maybe if Senator Patterson asks me in the next session she will get the answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Having regard to the fact that the Department of Administrative Services (DAS) is conducting what might be described as a recycling day in this building today by conducting several seminars on the subject, is the Minister able to demonstrate that the Government is taking effective action to improve all aspects of recycling in Australia? What action has the Government taken, firstly, to facilitate the manufacture of products from collected recyclables; secondly, to encourage the public to purchase products made from recycled materials; and thirdly, to increase the level of the Government's purchasing of products made from recycled materials?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset it should be made clear that the Government has a commitment to improve recycling in Australia. The commitment is directed at two levels: first, to increase the awareness of the importance of recycling-so in that regard education campaigns are important-and, secondly, through increased awareness both government and private responses to recycling can be augmented and increased.

ANSWER.PARA: The most recent commitment was spelt out by the Prime Minister in his July 1989 statement. Consequent to that statement on the environment, the Government initiated a review conducted by the Department of Administrative Services on the potential for using recycled paper. That was one response emanating from the Prime Minister's statement of July 1989. DAS was chosen because of its diverse roles in government. It is a purchaser; it has a technical role through bodies such as the Government laboratories, waste and cleaning through the Transport and Storage Group; and it supplies, of course, heaps of non-personalised stationery to members and senators. So the review was conducted, it reported in October 1989, and 29 recommendations emanated from that. As I say, those recommendations went to the question of educating as well as to the question of in-house decision-making in government to promote recycling.

Senator Bell asked a number of questions. I will go to the question of government action in this area in a few seconds, but in respect of the action that the Government has taken to facilitate the manufacture of products from collected recyclables, I think it is fair to instance one particular case, and that is the Government's involvement in and encouragement of a newspaper recycling mill at Albury-Wodonga. That was done with the encouragement of Senator Richardson and the Government, and I think that would be a great step in the cause of recycling. I think it is also fair to say that the Government anticipates another announcement within the next few months in the same sort of area.

In terms of encouraging the public to purchase products made from recycled materials, I, in my previous capacity as Minister for Consumer Affairs, together with other consumer Ministers, initiated a review, a program, to lead to the establishment of identification of consumer products to ensure that when consumers are purchasing they can make decisions on environmental grounds. That particular proposal has been picked up by the State and Federal Ministers for the environment and is being progressed by government. It has to be coordinated on a national and State level, and I anticipate from what I have been informed that that continuing process will come to some sort of culmination in the next few months as well.

Within government we have a number of roles. One is awareness, as I have mentioned, and today's seminars are an important part of that. The guide to the use of recycled paper, which is being launched today, is an important step and one that encourages better paper management but also raises awareness of the usefulness of recycling.

The other important arm of government is purchasing. It is interesting to note that we purchase thousands of tonnes of paper through the Purchasing and Sales Group of the Department. DAS spends $28.5m a year on paper contracts, the Government Printer spends another $26.5m, and we have a whole host of paper supplied to parliamentarians, as I said earlier. Over the last year we have entered contracts covering a variety of paper products that are made from recycled paper-continuous computer paper, writing pads, scribble pads, envelopes and 1991 diaries-and we are progressing with negotiations to ensure that that is extended for the next financial year to cover areas such as photocopy paper and fax paper as well as refills. I could go on--

TALK.START.PARA: —Please don't.

—I think Senator Newman said `Please do'. In response to that, I also indicate very briefly that we have a role in terms of technical awareness in the area. Government laboratories and the Archives can and do provide information on issues such as effects of time and frequent handling on recycled paper and the testing of whether paper is bleached or unbleached. We also have a role in relation to waste recycling.

ANSWER.PARA: There are a number of priorities in train for the future. I had discussions yesterday with the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and we are concerned about the lack of take-up of recycled paper in government and also within the Parliament. I will soon be writing to members of parliament to alert them to the fact that recycled paper is available for them. I believe that there might be a bit of a hiccup, Mr President, in regard to the Senate taking up recycled paper, as against the House of Representatives, but that is an issue that we will also have to focus on. That is one area of priority for the future. The other is to ensure that we pay adequate attention to the area of waste and cleaning contracts in order to improve recycling rates in that area as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Social Security to the Government's pre-election announcement of a total revamp of the unemployment benefits system. In light of the fact that the total budget for unemployment benefits is well in excess of $3 billion per annum and that, according to the economic statement of February 1989, `there will be no automatic transition from one payment to the other', can the Minister explain why such a new active income support structure will save only $21m in its first financial year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fairly simple answer to Senator Sheil's question is that the Newstart program, which is the main change, starts in July next year for all beneficiaries. At the moment we have got three levels.
—Why the urgency?

—I get one sentence out and Senator Alston starts asking about other things. I would just like to answer Senator Sheil for the moment, and then Senator Alston can have his go. I point out that we have got three benefits-one for the young, one for the youngish, and an unemployment benefit generally. As of next year there will only be two. There will not be unemployment benefits as such. There will be those on Newstart and another benefit for the first twelve months. So during the course of this financial year one would not expect great savings. However, the fact that for all beneficiaries we have considerably tightened up work and activity tests means that savings are being achieved all the time. It does not mean that more cannot be done to tighten the system up, although I think the changes in the last few years have gone a long way to making sure that we have much more efficiency in the system.

ANSWER.PARA: I think next year when Newstart comes into being for the great bulk of unemployment beneficiaries, some real savings will be seen and there will be opportunities for even the long-term unemployed to have a real chance of securing proper employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. In the light of the Minister's answer, and the never-never program he seems to have, will he not concede that there will not be a reduction in the number of long-term unemployed but, rather, the reverse?

—I think it is a hazardous business for the Minister for Social Security to predict unemployment levels and I will not do it. Irrespective of the level, if the honourable senator is saying that within it the number of long-term unemployed is likely to increase and not decrease, I do not agree. The Government's initiatives that were announced by the Prime Minister in the campaign to ensure that there will be not only more in the way of activity testing but also much more in the way of training, especially under Newstart, for the long-term unemployed, will, I have absolutely no doubt, effect a reduction in that number over the next two years.

—My question is to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in this morning's Australian Financial Review indicating that the Opposition spokesman on industrial relations, Mr Howard, has signalled a shift in the coalition's policy on union amalgamations? In the article, the claim is made that Mr Howard is moving towards the Japanese style of industrial relations with a multitude of small unions as a way of breaking down craft unionism. I ask the Minister how would he assess the impact of such a policy when compared with the impact of the Government's policy of amalgamations to achieve a small number of large industry-based unions along the lines of the German model?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have read the article in this morning's Australian Financial Review and it does, as Senator Beahan said, report a theoretical debate Mr Howard is having with himself about union amalgamations. Whether it signifies a fundamental shift in Opposition policy is, at this stage, hard to discern.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. In relation to the general question, that is to say the question predicated upon asking the Minister to comment on what are claimed to be aspects of Opposition policy, I put it to you in the first instance that that is not within the Minister's responsibility. If the Minister, however, claims that he has some responsibility in that, I put it to you that he has similarly condemned himself in his own last comment by describing the debate as a hypothetical debate, since the Standing Orders specifically proscribe questions being asked which are of a hypothetical nature.

—I would remind the Minister that he cannot accept responsibility for matters that are alleged to be contained in the policies of the non-Government party. What he can do is comment on whether the Government will implement those policies or not, and he should stay within the areas of his own responsibility.
—Thank you, Mr President. Of course, I believe that so far I have stayed within those areas- -
—Don't reflect on the Chair; just have a go and answer the question within the Standing Orders.
—Just you sit and wait for the answer.
—Order!

—The questions raised in the article about union amalgamations are, of course, questions of current political debate. They are matters reported more widely, in terms of this Government's intention, in an announcement I made when I first took over this portfolio to review the Industrial Relations Act in order that the objectives of the Act and facilities provided within the Act for union amalgamations might be considered for change in the Budget session of Parliament this year. That relates to a review of the Act that I am undertaking, and on which I have consulted with employers, unions, and a number of other key figures and commentators in order that the question of the amalgamations might be speedily resolved. In that context, the issues canvassed in the newspaper article referred to by Senator Beahan have been canvassed by other people and, I notice, now by Mr Howard. Therefore, I would argue that they are entirely consistent and within the purview of my ministerial responsibility.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me comment on some of those ideas. I do not think that the proposal for a Japanese-style trade union structure in Australia is a sensible or substantial proposal. It would envisage the creation of several thousand unions based on workplaces. While it might achieve the objective of breaking down the craft nature of Australian unions, it does beg the questions of how would that transition ever be made, given the fundamental opposition by the union movement itself to such a change; what the cost of such a transition would be; and whether or not the wider economy would be advantaged in terms of the direction the Government wants to take union amalgamation policy, that is, to create a greater industry focus in order to provide career paths, end demarcation disputes, and provide a more multi-skilled and supple work force, which is better able to direct itself to trainee and competency based wage increases through a training system rather than the craft structure we have now. That ought to be recognised as a fundamental shift.

I think in terms of this wider debate certainly Mr Howard has a view and that view ought to be considered but, in terms of the practicality of that view, I do not think it is realistic and it is not really applicable in the current circumstances. I think we will await my consideration of the various views that have been put when I announce and bring forward legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is the Minister aware that Australian Airlines has decided to withdraw the independent Ita magazine from all its Flight Deck lounges. If so, what is the reason for the decision? SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to clarify its economic policies which have been thrown into confusion by the public quarrel between the Treasurer and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce.

The Australian economy is in very serious trouble. The fundamental problems confronting the economy are more deep-seated than they have been since the Second World War. They are more intractable, and the longer they are left to fester the more difficult they will be to cure, the more intractable they will become. Just four years ago the Treasurer (Mr Keating) gave his famous banana republic speech when he warned that Australia was fast going down the Argentinean road of stagnation, hyperinflation and falling living standards.

Today the Australian economy is in a worse condition than it was four years ago. Our situation has deteriorated. The Senate does not have to take just my word for that-it is a view held by most serious economic commentators and economists. It is also the view held by Senator Walsh, the Minister for Finance until two weeks ago.

The symptoms of our economic malaise are plain for all to see: inflation stuck in a high groove of 7 to 9 per cent, twice the average of our major trading partners, with little prospect of falling and, indeed, some real prospect of rising; interest rates the highest in the Western World; foreign debt now totalling almost $150 billion; a gross current account deficit of $148.1m at the end of December; a current account balance which will be in deficit to the tune probably of $20 billion this year, making a total accumulated deficit over the period of the Hawke Government of $95 billion; productivity growth at best stagnant; negative economic growth; and per capita incomes falling.

This fundamental, intractably difficult situation should be occupying the total, undivided attention of the Government and particularly its key economic Ministers, especially the Treasurer, the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button). But what do we find instead? We find a government very deeply divided, a government in a self-destruct mode, a government where all concept of Cabinet solidarity has disappeared, a government led by a Prime Minister who has very rightly earned the description by his erstwhile former Finance Minister of Old Jellyback. Why that description? Because the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has patently failed to exert the leadership over his Ministry, the discipline and the unity that is essential if government is to tackle responsibly the great problems facing us.

Three days ago we witnessed the most vitriolic, public, humiliating attack by one senior Minister-none less than the Deputy Prime Minister himself-on another senior colleague that we have seen in the memory of most of us. That attack breached Cabinet solidarity, Cabinet confidentiality and all normal Cabinet conventions.

The Prime Minister should have sacked his Deputy Prime Minister and Treasurer for such breaches, but he did not do so. Instead he supported Mr Keating in his condemnation of Senator Button. The Prime Minister thereby became party to an unholy alliance with his Deputy against the Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce-the third most senior Minister in his Government.

If the Prime Minister believed the Treasurer should be supported in his brutal damning attack on Senator Button he should have sacked Senator Button for ministerial incompetence. Again he failed to show the leadership required of a Prime Minister. Looking at it from another point of view, why was it left to Mr Keating to do the attempted hatchet job on Senator Button? Why did the Prime Minister abrogate that responsibility if there was so much concern about Senator Button's comments? It was only after the event that the Prime Minister got into the act. The dirty work had been done by then. It was only after that that he told Senator Button to button up. The problem is that Mr Hawke is unprepared, as Prime Minister, to take the necessary tough decisions. Senator Walsh is right: the Prime Minister is an Old Jellyback.

The result of all of this is monumental division and disunity within the Cabinet. As a result there will be confusion in the community, particularly the business community, as to just what the Government's economic policies are. Who does one believe in this Government-the Treasurer, who says that there is no severe downturn in the economy, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, who says that there is a severe downturn in the economy, or the Minister for Finance who says that there may be a severe downturn in the economy but he does not really know?

This Government is disintegrating. It is disintegrating because of very deep and internal divisions and a lack of leadership. Mr Keating tried to usurp the Prime Minister throughout 1988 and much of 1989 and I think that what has been happening in recent days is a resurrection of that campaign. Honourable senators may recall that a year or so ago he actually sent his lackey, Mr Dawkins, to tell the Prime Minister that he should stand aside for Mr Keating.

We have had the merciless public rubbishing of the New South Wales heavyweight and our colleague here-the then Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson-by his Cabinet colleague Mr Kerin from late 1989 on because of Senator Richardson's servile, cynical, opportunistic, obsequiousness to the radical greens. We have had Mr Kerin's dumping on the whole Cabinet for its pusillanimous acceptance of the Richardson line, a line that cost Australia billions of investment dollars and even more billions of precious export income as a result of aborted development projects, the most notable of which were Wesley Vale and Coronation Hill.

We have had former Finance Minister Senator Walsh's bucketing of Senator Richardson immediately after the election for prostituting rational decision-making on the matter and replacing it with grubby vote buying overtures to the radicals in the important environment movement.

We have had Senator Walsh's monumental rubbishing of his former Cabinet colleagues immediately after his outright refusal to serve in the Hawke Ministry announced a week after the election. His proclamations have been brutal and devastating. They range from his declaration that the Government lacks the courage to take the necessary hard economic decisions to his now famous description of his Prime Minister. This is from a man who has been one of the key economic Ministers throughout the seven years of the Hawke Government.

There have been many other outbursts of disloyalty, despair, frustration and accusation by Ministers of this so-called Government over recent weeks. There are too many to name them all, but a few are worthy of mention. All are noteworthy because they involve accusation by Minister against Minister, undermining Minister against Minister and destruction of the basic concept of collective Cabinet solidarity. A couple of these cannot be allowed to escape repeated exposure.

I refer first to the devastating public criticism of the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, by the Prime Minister last week when, in the full glare of the floor of the House of Representatives, the Prime Minister said of Senator Tate that he had exercised `an appalling lapse of judgment' in making public comments presuming the guilt of a person under arrest on a drug charge. What more damning comment could a Prime Minister make of one of his Ministers-`an appalling lapse of judgment'? But what was the outcome? The Prime Minister lacked the spine to sack Senator Tate and Senator Tate lacked the decency, the basic sense of ministerial responsibility, to resign.

Another example of the disarray and disloyalty which is now endemic within the Government's own ranks, and which is causing fundamental confusion as to its economic policies and policies generally, was the outburst this week by the now Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and until recently Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, that he was persistently and consistently undermined by several of his colleagues whilst Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.

But the supreme demonstration of disarray, disaffection, dislike, disloyalty, division and decay came three days ago when the Deputy Prime Minister took to the streets outside the Parliament to do his job on Senator Button.

In 1988 there was a monumental struggle within the Cabinet as to control of the basic instrument that was to lead us towards economic reform in terms of structural and micro-economic reform-namely, the then Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) and now the Industry Commission. After a great struggle the Treasurer won again and Senator Button missed out. Several damaging events then occurred. The Treasurer failed, until the very last moment, to appoint enough commissioners to allow the Commission to function legally and then he filled the positions only on a stop-gap basis. Ministers, including Senator Button, refused to allow the IAC to examine their industry assistance programs. It soon became evident that the Treasurer was not really interested in micro-economic reform. He even described micro-economic reform as small beer, despite it ostensibly having been made the top priority for the Government's third term of office between 1987 and 1989. Nothing was done then. The Government has now claimed it to be its top priority again during its fourth term. But we can be certain that the actuality will be no more action to match the hollow rhetoric that we have seen in the past three years.

Already the scope for structural reform-that is what so-called micro-reform is-has been massively circumscribed by the Government in the last three or four weeks alone. Meaningful labour market reform has been ruled out by the Government's insistence on adherence to the costly wage-tax deal with the unions and by its violent negative reaction to the Opposition's proposals to permit much greater flexibility in voluntary dealings between employers and employees in terms and conditions of employment. Any prospects for improving the efficiency of government business enterprises through privatisation have been ruled out. As a result, there is every likelihood that more taxpayers' money will go into business enterprises that should be deriving capital from the private sector.

This week we have had the public disputation between the Treasurer and Senator Button, the relevant Minister, as to their approach to tariff reform and tariff reduction. We have had the extraordinary situation where there was a public attack by the Treasurer on the Minister because he was alleged to be dragging his heels on the whole area of tariff reform, and then within 48 hours the Treasurer said that in fact the tariff reforms that have occurred were done on Senator Button's own initiative. That statement is totally irreconcilable with the thrust of the public bucketing by the Treasurer of Senator Button three days earlier.

The Treasurer has tried to portray himself as the great reformer. Why then has he not said one word to Senator Button about any speeding up of the review into the arrangements for the future of the textile, clothing and footwear industries? Why did he object so violently to Senator Button's recommendations in Cabinet about the handling of the review into the car industry? Every indication and every action by the Treasurer has been against the need for and acceptance of the importance of economic reform despite all the rhetoric that has been spoken.

I want to preserve some time for my colleague Senator Chapman to speak for longer than the five minutes he would otherwise be entitled to at the end of this debate so I will conclude my remarks on that note other than to say this: this Government cannot govern itself, and a Government that cannot govern itself cannot govern the nation.

It is essential that the Government get its act together, heal its divisiveness, take the tough decisions and get the economy going again in the right direction. The divisiveness and the resulting confusion that has occurred as a result of the inability of this Government and its senior economic Ministers to act together cohesively and in unity is causing great damage, uncertainty, confusion and falling confidence throughout the Australian community. Regrettably all the signs are that it will be impossible for the Government to correct this. It is for that reason that the Opposition has raised this matter of urgency today and I urge the Senate to support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer to the terms of the urgency motion which has been moved by Senator Short, because he did not. I think it is very important in any sense of intellectual discipline to adhere to what we are supposed to be debating. The terms of the urgency motion are:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to clarify its economic policies-
there is always a need, I suppose, for governments, oppositions and commentators to clarify their economic views-
which have been thrown into confusion by the public quarrel between the Treasurer and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce.

The Canberra Times this morning, in an editorial relating to the car plan, which is crassly misinformed on matters of fact, refers to the fact that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) took me to task for a remark on the direction of economic policy. I just want to remind this Senate that Senator Short, if he were to establish this urgency motion for one moment, had to point to a difference between me and the Treasurer on the direction of economic policy. He totally failed to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —He cannot even agree on the direction of your policy.

—In not one remark. Senator Short is making his final speech before leaving for nicer climes at the end of the week. I wish I were going with him! If he were to establish the text of his motion he had to point to a difference about the directions of economic policy between the Treasurer and me. He failed to do so. The Canberra Times this morning refers to a remark I made about the direction of economic policy, though whoever wrote the editorial is as ill-informed as Senator Short. I made no such remarks. If Senator Short had been here--
—Tell us Keating is a good bloke and we will believe you.

—I did not say that, Senator. If Senator Short had been here last year at Question Times-and he was for many Question Times-he would have heard me again and again defending the direction of the Government's economic policy, an economic policy which the Government spokesmen at that time, including me, admitted, in terms of high interest rates, was hurting people in the Australian community.
—You are defending the indefensible.

—Senator Baume's interjection is that I am `defending the indefensible'. Those opposite pretended throughout last year that they would do something about interest rates if they got into government at the election. Their leader at the time of the election had been elected to the leadership as a result of a stabbing in the back of John Howard. He had been elected on the basis of opinion polls to lead the Liberal Party into the election, claiming at election time that the coalition would reduce interest rates from day one if elected to government in the course of that election.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition was not elected to government, for very good reasons. Only this week the Sydney Morning Herald talked about the Opposition's attack on Government economic policy in the first major economic speech from the new shadow Treasurer, Mr Peter Reith, and said that he failed `to articulate any alternative economic position'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is nonsense.

—Senator Short says that is nonsense; I thought today he would have taken the opportunity which was right there in his hands to articulate an alternative economic position. He did not articulate one word of an alternative position. In terms of economic policy the main arms of the Government's economic policy are fiscal policy, wages policy and monetary policy. It has been very difficult for this Government to administer, as we have done, a tight monetary policy. There has been no difference between any Minister in the Government about the need to maintain a tight monetary policy, as we did last year and have continued to do, with some relaxation, in the earlier part of this calendar year.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been no difference between any Ministers in the Government on that issue or about the need for a tight fiscal policy. A tight fiscal policy is something which those opposite would know nothing about, leaving us, as they did in 1983, with an enormous deficit, which this Government has turned into a surplus. They knew nothing about it. They do not talk about fiscal policy now because they really do not know anything about it. In terms of wages policy they bleat away--
Opposition senators interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are those opposite all yelling their heads off? Is this painful to them? I think it might be. They never talk about wages policy with any sense at all. This Government has administered a wages policy which has been both practicable and fair. Those two things are absolutely necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year I listened to those opposite talking about the decline in the living standard of Australians. When we came into office 600,000 people were out in the streets without jobs. But last year those opposite were talking about declining living standards, using the measure relating to average weekly earnings. We used the measure relating to household disposable income. We chose an improvement in Australian living standards, and that is because people have been employed under this Government. Those opposite have nothing to say about that because they have nothing of any sense to say about anything.

In the course of Senator Short's speech, which was supposed to be dealing with the directions of Government economic policy, about which there are no differences between Ministers, he wandered off down the old track which he has talked about on many occasions in this place before. He talked about a monumental struggle between the Treasurer and me over the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC), as it then was.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you got rolled again.

—Those opposite know who determines the administrative arrangements. It is the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I tell Senator Short now that as far as I am aware, the Treasurer did not even seek to have the IAC in his portfolio. There was no power struggle between the Treasurer and me on that issue. There was a decision by the Government that the Industries Commission, as it now is, should be used to look at wider economic issues than the specialist industry by industry reviews which it had conducted in the past. The Government having made that decision, it is totally appropriate for the Industry Commission to be within the aegis of the Treasurer.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short forgets that while the Industries Assistance Commission was in my portfolio, we adopted every one of its recommendations except those in respect of chemicals and plastics where, as I said yesterday, we lowered the tariffs further than the IAC wanted us to do, and the textiles, clothing and footwear industries. Those are the two exceptions.

In March 1988 we announced an across-the-board phase down of tariffs in industry. Once there is that process of an across-the-board tops down approach to tariff reductions, the IAC, as the body looking at individual industries, has limited relevance. The Government made a decision to use it for economy-wide references, as it has since done. So, if Senator Short wants to lay the groundwork for what has happened this week by looking back to conspiracies which allegedly happened in 1987 or 1988, he is again quite wrong.

I do not want to lecture the Opposition in any sense at all, but I do wish that it would understand that there is a difference between the direction of economic policy and its consequences. The words used in Senator Short's matter of public importance are `the need . . . to clarify its economic policies'. There is no need for clarification on that issue at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —You go and ask any one in the business community about that. You know that is wrong. They do not know where you are at in terms of economic policy.

—That is not correct. There are many differences in the business community about the consequences of current economic policies in terms of still relatively tight monetary policy and so on. But there are not differences or misunderstandings in the business community-I keep in pretty close touch with them; they do not talk to me about directions of economic policy but they talk to me about the consequences of current economic policies. It is natural for them to do so, as I am the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. There are differences of agreement and of emphasis on the consequences for different sectors of the economy. As the Treasurer said, I think yesterday, the economy is patchy in terms of the consequences of economic policy. Some people are feeling it more than others. That is a fact from which no Minister in this Government retreats.

SPEECH.PARA: I have used some words about the effects of current economic circumstances on sectors of the business community, and so on; the Treasurer has used words which are no different. I think he said in the House of Representatives yesterday that it was purely a matter of emphasis in the terminology which was used. The point I am trying to make is that there is a difference between confusion on economic policies and confusion about the consequences-which there may well be in sectors of the community.

Senator Short, in his matter of urgency, goes on to talk about `the public quarrel between the Treasurer and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce' allegedly confusing economic policies. I said nothing at all in the now controversial Walsh Report interview about the directions of Government economic policy. The Treasurer subsequently made some remarks about tariff reform, which are well known. In answers to questions in this Senate on a series of occasions-Senator Short asked some of them-I have explained my views about those issues, as I am entitled to do. But to turn that seeming disagreement about these issues-Senator Short made the point that the Treasurer in Question Time yesterday or the day before had qualified considerably some of his earlier remarks-into a question of confusion about the Government's economic policies is ridiculous. I regard this--

TALK.START.PARA: —Keating said he did not agree with you about a severe downturn. He said it in the House of Representatives yesterday.
—Senator Baume has wandered in, has he?
—I have been listening with great attention to your nonsense.
—I saw Senator Baume before nodding his head; I thought he was asleep. Perhaps he agreed with what I was saying.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short has brought a matter of urgency here which is totally ill-conceived in terms of its terminology and in terms of the plain meaning of the English language. —It is true. The shadow Minister for industry and commerce, Mr McLachlan, has now become the Opposition spokesman on agricultural policy. Presumably, Senator Short will be away when he has to defend the position which I have just put to him.

SPEECH.PARA: Differences between Opposition spokesmen on industrial relations issues are clear. The Opposition has had eight years to sort out these issues but differences are still emerging about industrial relations policies. They were raised at Question Time today, and at this stage Mr Howard is having a massive rethink about Opposition policy on these issues.

There are mild differences of emphasis between Ministers in what has been said about that issue. Why did Senator Short not point to the Government spokesman who had used the word `recession'?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance.

—The Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) did not use the word `recession', except in a very qualified sense. If Senator Short wanted to mount any sort of credible attack on the Government, I would have though that that would have been the linchpin of his argument. I do not regard this as a credible attack and I ask the Senate to reject it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this urgency motion with more sorrow than anger. I suppose the anger has disappeared after five Parliaments in this place. It does seem to me to be a pity that after the last election, with the Opposition still in opposition, its members would have learnt that they needed to change by focusing on policy and forgetting about the personalities. But yet again, we have a matter of urgency focusing on personalities, running that rather silly line that I think the electorate is well and truly tired of.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not normally agree with Gerard Henderson in his Media Watch, but I must say that I was flicking through it last night and it came to mind this morning when I saw the Opposition's so-called urgency motion. He referred to a number of follies involving the Australian media in election mode. One of them in fact referred to Senator Button, and there was an unflattering photograph of him attached to the article as well. That was Folly No. 3-`An Obsession with Minor Errors'. At the end of this discussion about the problems that occur in terms of miscalculations or so-called scoops, there is a lesson for the future which I think is important. It says:
Journalists on the election trail should not cast the first stone. They should treat the minor miscalculations of others in the same manner as they treat their own slip-ups-i.e. by overlooking them.

I think that is excellent advice. The quite innocuous statements made by Senator Button on a television program quite frankly, I think, had absolutely nothing to do with the economic debate in this country and it is a pity that as a matter of urgency we did not have the Opposition bringing forward something of substance. Indeed, I think the focus on this debate could very well have been on the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and his propositions with regard to what is the fundamental economic debate-that is the terms of trade. But we have not got that. We did not have it yesterday in the other economic debate, and we do not have it again today. Presumably at some stage people are going to get tired of talking about personalities and get on to the issues.

The issue in terms of the terms of trade, of course, is that if the Government has got it wrong, we are certainly going to find out in the next couple of years. The terms of trade is the only thing that really we need to focus on. At the time of the last election we made it very clear that for a number of reasons we, as a party, were unhappy with the direction in which the Government was going.
