We believe that, for example, resources will not go into import replacement industries unless they can earn a higher rate of return, and the problem with high interest rates, of course, is that they discriminate against investment in comparison to consumption.

But over all of this, I think there is an extraordinary exercise in priorities-not only the priorities of the Opposition but also, if one bothers to flick through them, the priorities of the media. Let us look at what was given high priority yesterday-high priority, of course, in terms of what the media see as being important. They put high priority on the operation the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is going to have, and low priority on the conclusions of the international conference with regard to the environment and the agreement between the industrialised countries not to assist less industrialised countries overcome the problem of ozone depletion. They saw the operation of the Prime Minister-a minor matter, quite frankly, both in personal and certainly political terms-to be high priority; they saw these other matters to be low priority.

The Opposition members, running as they do the exercise of trying to get themselves a few brownie points and hopefully a headline here or there, have decided to adopt exactly the same tactic. I think they are selling the electorate short by doing that and I think that the electorate, unless it gets better service from the Opposition, will keep them there for a long time.

The item which got included in this debate which I want to focus on is overseas debt. That involves economic policies which I think need to be enunciated much more clearly. Here, again, we have had another one of those fallacies running around: we say the size of Australia's debt is a very large number and of course debt is bad, and you fill in your own particular assertion at that point. The difficulty, of course, is that the debate about overseas debt with regard to Australia has not been discussed in rational terms. Indeed, on one particular calculation, if we wish to take debt as a percentage of our net capital stock, that is in terms of our buildings, our equipment and our constructions, it in fact is 11 per cent. This is the normal exercise of working out whether we are heavily geared or not. If we wanted to add into that the land, the resources, and the financial assets, nobody could possibly claim that Australia, as a country, was heavily geared.

The really absurd exercise, though, is this one of saying that every Australian somehow or other owns this debt. It is almost as nonsensical, of course, as suggesting that every Australian is responsible for 0.00002 of every murder that is committed in Australia. They are not; neither is every Australian responsible for the debt. The debt, and the correctness of decisions with regard to debt, are a matter not of a debt is bad, no debt is good type of simplistic reaction. Borrowings are judged on the basis of what we borrow for.

Most Australians are happy to and want to be in the position to borrow for a home. That does not make those borrowings bad, provided the money is put to good use-that is, they are buying a home-and they can service the debt. The judgment about debt is made in terms of outcome and sustenance, not in terms of debt is bad, no debt is good. In terms of the money that has come into Australia by way of borrowings, quite frankly the jury is still out. We do not know whether those borrowings have been put to good use.

But one of the things that we do know-and the Opposition in the last Parliament made a great deal of noise about this particular matter-is that we have had a downgrading of our credit rating. It is an even more odd exercise to get upset about that, because if one is upset about the level of debt, why would one be upset about a downgrading of credit ratings? A downgrading of credit ratings means that we have less ability to borrow.

So, in terms of that exercise, all it means is that if a high foreign debt is seen as a problem, the existence of that debt prevents us from further increasing our foreign borrowings. I would have thought that Opposition members would be happy with that position. But, instead, they run the two contradictory lines that the high foreign debt is bad and that the downgrading of our credit rating is bad. That is absurd.

To the extent, of course, that the money that has come in has produced products, and these products are competitive, then over time we will see the outcome of that productive investment. In so far as those investments have been bad investments, then it is a judgment on the people that have spent that money, and a judgment on the people who loaned that money-that is, a judgment on the banks and other financial institutions in this country for lending money to people who should not have been able to get that money, and secondly, on private enterprise in terms of its investments. But we have had a lot of Opposition members saying, as we have had other commentators saying, `Government should take some action'. I simply ask the question: What particular action do people want government to take? Do they want government interfering in the investment policies of private enterprise? I would have thought that the Opposition would say no to that. Do we want bureaucrats making decisions about what happens? I would have thought that the Opposition would say no to that too. We have heard nothing from the Opposition. I had hoped that in the early days of this new Parliament we would have heard something about the particular policies the Opposition thinks the Government should put in place with regard to the foreign debt. But as yet we have not heard anything.

The exercises on those investments and the discussions that have been carried out so far have been of a highly artificial kind. For example, during the election campaign I heard an Opposition spokesperson maintain that a lot of the money that has come in has been poorly spent. I am not quite sure how that person made such a judgment, but there was a reference in the speech to the non-traded sector, such as insurance, freight and the like. I believe that investments in those areas have had very important implications for the cost structure of the traded sector. But our infrastructure has to be continually modernised. For example, the suggestion that we should not have spent so much on computers seems to me a little like suggestions, made when Edison invented the electric light, that we should not get into electricity because gas was cheaper. We have to stay current; we have to stay competitive. If those expenditures are poorly done, we will see the results, not in gross terms of money being spent on computerisation, but in the fact that the money will be spent in the wrong way and in the wrong areas. However, I have not yet seen either industry or others bringing forward definite propositions that that money has been spent incorrectly.

Somebody has suggested that the money should not have been spent on housing. My party does not see the economy as existing in its own right. We see its purpose as that of providing goods and services that benefit the population. If that benefit flows through to the population in the form of housing, we see that as a benefit, not a disbenefit, to the economy.

On the question of our high foreign debt, to the extent that lending to Australia declines because of our credit rating, we will find that further downward pressure will be put on that debt. That appears to be a good thing. To blame the Government for private sector debt seems very odd and I have not yet heard what type of action the Government is expected to take in relation to the private sector. To date, the arguments are lacking in compulsion with regard to the need to increase efficiency and competitiveness. I would point to this factor because throughout the election that was the only thread that I was able to pick up that was consistent in what the Opposition said.

There is no necessary relationship between a more competitive economy and lower foreign debt-none whatsoever. A more competitive economy may lead to lower foreign debt, but on the other hand it may lead to higher foreign debt. The reason for that is obvious. International lenders are not in the area of charity and if they do lend they are likely to lend to those people who, hopefully, can repay. A more active and competitive economy would have a greater capacity to pay and, hence, a greater capacity to raise its debt.

These are the matters which we should be debating, not the rather silly matter of urgency that is before the Senate. We see no urgency in the matter that has been brought forward and, hence, we will not be supporting it. We hope that next time such a matter is put forward it will be urgent so that we can discuss the real issues of the economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is it that Australians have to pay through the nose for so many goods and services which they require to meet their everday needs? Why do we have to pay double what people in many other countries would pay for most of the cars on the Australian market? Why do Australians have to pay $160 for a pair of Nike Pegasus running shoes when Americans pay only $82? Why do we have to pay $600 for the same suit that even New Zealanders can get for $450? Why does even our own culture cost more in Australia than it does overseas? Young Australians have to pay $17.99 for Kylie Minogue's latest record album, Enjoy Yourself, while Americans pay only $8.99. That is some capacity to enjoy themselves! Even Robert Hughes' best seller The Fatal Shore costs Australians $15.95 while Americans pay only $14.99 and the British $12.59.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason for these outrageous prices in Australia is, according to Mr Keating, that Senator Button has been dragging the chain. Mr Keating says that Senator Button does not want to cut tariffs as much as he does. Mr Keating says that Senator Button wants to do private deals with car companies and other clients of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce about future levels of protection. Mr Keating says that prices would be even worse if Senator Button had his way on consumption tax.

But according to Senator Button, it is Mr Keating's fault. It is because of macro-economic circumstances. Senator Button says that we face these problems because Mr Keating has not brought the current account deficit under control. Senator Button says that Mr Keating's policies have produced an economic downturn of some severity, reducing our living standards. Senator Button says that Mr Keating's policies have caused a decline in investment and investment intentions in Australia.

Sadly for all Australians, who seem to have been completely forgotten in the midst of all the quarrelling, divisions and rancour between these two senior Ministers, which has become the hallmark of this Hawke Labor Government in its fourth term, both are right and both are wrong. Both are right because the continued featherbedding of large sections of Australian industry, with excessive protection and a regulated labour market as well as the wrong macro-economic policies of high interest rates, high taxation and, consequently, high inflation, together are causing prices to spiral and living standards to go through the floor.

That is why Senator Short and I, on behalf of the Opposition, are arguing as a matter of urgency today for `the need for the Government to clarify its economic policies which have been thrown into confusion by the public quarrel between the Treasurer and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce'.

A few moments ago in his very lame response to this debate, Senator Button said that to establish the terms of the motion we had to show that there were differences between Ministers on the direction of economic policy. Certainly, in the community there is concern about the direction of economic policy. Certainly, there are differences between these Ministers as to the correct rate of change in the structure of our economy. Certainly, as we have also seen from their statements this week, there are differences between these Ministers as to the health of our economy. So, for the sake of all Australians, let us hope that Old Jellyback gets that desperately needed spine transplant while his other physical problems are sorted out in that Sydney hospital. Then he can knock some heads together and instil some unity and sense of purpose into his tired, uninspired and uninspiring Government.

With the economy in recession, Australia cannot afford to have this Government starting its fourth term in office by being unable to give itself and its Ministers a sense of direction, unable to lay down clearly its program for the next three years, unable to provide us with stability and unity of purpose and, most importantly, unable to show strong leadership. All we see coming from this Government is division and rancour. No wonder people in the community are confused when they see this occurring in a government whose leader proudly trumpeted during the last election campaign that a party which cannot govern itself cannot govern the country. Indeed, a party which cannot govern itself cannot govern the country. This is the very position in which Labor has been ever since the election. No wonder the Australian people are flocking to support the coalition, as evidenced by yesterday's Morgan gallup poll. In contrast with the Government, the Opposition now offers a competent and united team, committed to making the changes necessary to ensure Australia's economic recovery and future prosperity.

But sadly, Australia cannot wait until the next election for these initiatives. They are urgently needed right now. Just as sadly, this Government's senior Ministers cannot agree on the required action or initiate it. So, home buyers, small businesses and farmers have been forced to bleed by high interest rates and a consequently over-valued dollar. All this Government can agree to do is to restrain the burgeoning trade deficit and foreign debt by dampening demand.

What Australia really needs is to increase its product and to produce more goods and services which are internationally competitive, and therefore capable of replacing imports without the protective shield of tariffs or quotas and earn export dollars for this country. This has not happened, according to the Treasurer, because Senator Button lacks sufficient zeal to reduce tariffs and likes doing deals with industry behind closed doors. What hypocrisy from the Treasurer! From whom does he think Senator Button learned about doing deals? Above all else, this is a Government of deals and fixes, especially between big government, big unions and big business, under its corporate state mentality which allows no place for individuals, their rights or freedoms.

Foremost among the perpetrators of deals has been the Treasurer himself. Let us face it; he was weaned on them from his youth in the New South Wales Labor Party. Do honourable senators need to be reminded of his successive deals with Crean and Kelty, giving them de facto Cabinet status, allowing them to retain corporate power and status at the cost of delivering continually falling living standards to Australian workers-deals which prevented the deregulation of the labour market and the development of enterprise based industrial relations. What gall on the part of the Treasurer! How dare he condemn Senator Button for doing private deals! The fact is that this whole Government has been one of deals and fixes with the business and union mates of Hawke, Keating and Button.

All Australians should also remember, as they watch the Treasurer and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce squabble over a consumption tax, that largely because of the Treasurer's surreptitious changes to the existing sales tax we are now paying consumption tax to the tune of $9.4 billion per year. But even more sinister is the hidden consumption tax, the $7.7 billion extra which Australians have to pay for goods because of the continuation of excessive tariffs and quotas, which has been the subject of the squabble between the Ministers this week. Why would a government of secrecy, of private deals and fixes like this one want to be up front and honest with the Australian people by introducing a consumption tax when it is already ripping $17.1 billion out of their pockets in hidden taxes?

Senator Button has repeatedly talked about the need to add value to our primary products as a means of improving our trade balance. But yesterday he threw up his hands and blamed the experts when I asked him about the continuing crisis in the wool industry. Then today in this debate he sought to fabricate differences within the Opposition on wool policy. What about allowing the opportunity to add some value in Australia to this massive wool stockpile? Because the Minister has been dragging the chain on reducing protection, Australian wool scouring actually receives minus levels of protection; that is, the excessive protection on various inputs to this wool scouring industry makes what is an otherwise efficient industry less competitive on world markets. So much for this Government's commitment to value adding. It says volumes for the Government's attitude to the wool industry, which would gain enormous benefits from value adding.

This Government has offered no policy prescription which is effective in increasing the productivity and product output of Australian industry. Its policies have simply been designed to dampen down demand and in that way try to overcome our burgeoning trade deficit and our burgeoning foreign debt. For the Government it is too hard to increase product, because that involves changing the way we do things. It involves treading on some toes. It involves especially treading on the toes of some of the Government's union mates.

What this country needs to increase its product is a deregulated labour market, based on individual firms, the productivity of those firms and their capacity to pay. We need to have an industrial relations system which will allow effective profit sharing and give employees a stake in those firms. We need to abandon the `us and them' mentality that the Government's present centralised system of industrial relations encourages. Only then will we establish competitive export-oriented industries which, as I said earlier, not only can replace imports competitively without any need for protection but can also earn export dollars for this country, and in those two ways combine to reduce our massive and, as I say, continually burgeoning foreign debt. Australian industries need to be exposed to the chill winds of world competition which will provide them with the incentive to become more efficient.

We also need to dramatically lower the cost of transport in this country. Given the size of Australia, as well as its distance from international markets, the cost of transport is of much greater significance to our cost of production than it is for many other countries. But it is made even worse because of the effects of the power of the union movement with regard to restrictive work practices and union structure in rail transport, our waterfront and shipping industries. Unless we are prepared to bite the bullet and reform those industries, we have no hope of becoming internationally competitive.

Senator Macklin postulated that our overseas debt was not a problem, because it was only 11 per cent of our assets. What Senator Macklin ignored was the capacity of this country, through its earnings, to service that debt.

So the Opposition calls on the Treasurer and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to respond to this urgency motion by immediately acting to reduce protection and featherbedding more quickly, to reform the restrictive work practices and union domination in rail transport, on our wharves and in shipping, to deregulate the labour market and establish enterprise based industrial relations, and to cut government spending. Only then we will see the turn around in our economy and increasing prosperity for all Australians. The Government has been out on one long smoko for the last three years. It is time to get back on the job.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 31 of 1989-90-Report on Ministerial Portfolios-Autumn Sittings 1989-90.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I speak very briefly to the report. This is a very useful report by the Auditor-General. It would have been more useful had it been received by this chamber before the Senate Estimates committees that met this week in fact did meet. Many questions emerge out of this report which could, and in some instances should, have been raised in Senate Estimates committees and certainly would have been raised had senators been aware of the material that is in this report. I am certainly not blaming the Government for this, because one can clearly see that the report was conveyed to the Government on 17 May, according to the letter at the front. All I am saying is that this sort of timing is unfortunate. I hope that the Auditor-General recognises how useful his work is to senators in dealing with Senate Estimates. The timing of the Senate Estimates committees must have been available to all the authorities involved quite some time ago, and the significance of the points I am making would be evident from the fact that this report, for example, indicates that there has been an unacceptable level of breaches of legislation by statutory authorities in particular.

The Auditor-General notes that 18 statutory authorities were required to deal with receipt and expenditure of moneys and the acquisition of disposable assets in accordance with the law. The list of 18 contains major organisations such as the Australian National Gallery, the Australian Sports Commission, the Health Insurance Commission and so on. On top of that, legislative restraints on borrowing were breached by another series of organisations.

The Auditor-General does say that, while it should be noted that many of these breaches involved relatively small amounts for relatively short durations, and, where approvals had been required, they were later referred to a competent authority for information, nevertheless the number of organisations involved is of concern. If it is of concern, it would have been nice to have raised those concerns with the bodies involved at Senate Estimates.

I think most senators know that I am concerned about the matter of dead rent, and the Auditor-General's audit report had previously mentioned that dead rent amounting to $3.6m was involved in the Rialto building in Melbourne, and this was described by the Auditor-General as `excessive'. He also states:

Following further consideration of the comments provided by the Australian Construction Service, the Australian National Audit Office sought advice from the Department of Administrative Services and the Australian Bureau of Statistics, an occupant of the Rialto building, on the reasons for submissions of clients briefs at, or after, completion of the building-
which is one of the reasons for the dead rent-
since that appeared to the ANAO to have resulted in an avoidable dead rent cost of $1.6 million.

This sort of thing would have been significant and important enough to have been raised in some detail in Estimates committees. For example, we have had the Department of Veterans' Affairs estimates. The report states:
The audits of the accounts and records of the hospitals--
of the Department of Veterans' Affairs-
found deficiencies in the areas of salaries, payment of claims, stores and management information and reporting systems.
So it goes on throughout a whole range of departments. I might say, Mr President, in your area, the Parliamentary Information Systems Office, the report states:

The audit found a disregard for the established form of Commonwealth budgetary expenditure control and a number of breaches of legislation in that moneys received were not paid into the Consolidated Revenue Fund and were spent without appropriation and the exercise of other statutory processes.

I believe that these matters are sufficiently significant to merit being raised in the Committee of the Whole of the Senate itself when the Estimates committees report to this chamber. As a result of document like this report coming in late, I now feel obliged to tell the Secretary of each of the Estimates committees that the matters raised in this report merit a reservation in the committee reports. I am certain it would assist the procedures of this chamber if that sort of thing did not have to take place, but I give notice I will advise the Secretary of every Estimates committee that we should have the reservation enabling these matters to be raised in the appropriations debate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise but for one moment to express by concern at the outrageous situation in which we find ourselves in respect of the swearing in of a new senator from Western Australia. Senator Ian Campbell was endorsed by the Liberal Party on 30 April of this year, filling a casual vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Fred Chaney. The State Parliament has sat continuously since 1 May. It is now 17 May and Senator Campbell is still unable to take his place in this chamber. My understanding is that at 3 p.m. yesterday a meeting of both Houses of the Western Australian State Parliament took place, and Senator Campbell was duly appointed.

SPEECH.PARA: It is symptomatic of the problems of the Lawrence State Labor Government of Western Australia that it is so incompetent and incapable that the State of Western Australia-its State-has quite unnecessarily been denied a senator for a period. At this moment Senator Campbell is unable to be sworn in because the due processes and formalities have not been completed by the Western Australian State Government.

It is not without significance to note the contrast between that situation and the situation pertaining to Mr Goss, the Labor Premier of Queensland, who sought to make a political point and embarrass the National Party in Queensland when he called for an early endorsement to enable an early appointment. That was intended to flush out whether or not Mr Stone was to be submitted as the nominee of the National Party. It could do it in a flash, but the Western Australian State Labor Government, which has been sitting since 1 May-the Monday following the Sunday endorsement of the then Mr Campbell-is unable to find time for a two-minute joint sitting to appoint a new senator from Western Australia. It shows either total and absolute incompetence or total disregard for the proper representation of that State in this chamber and within that State. I suspect it is a combination of both.

There seems to be no clear indication when those processes are going to be duly completed so as to allow for Senator Campbell to be sworn in, to take his place in this chamber, and to fulfil his obligations and responsibilities on a number of appropriate committees. I condemn the State Labor Government for its failure. As I say, it is symptomatic of the imbroglio, the mess, the confusion and the incompetence into which it has presently plunged.
